subject: Re: [junit] J2ME and JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I already did it. Apologize me is my last e-mail wasn t clear enough, but what I was trying to tell that i believe JUnit uses the main method with parts
messageBody:
> You need to override the startApp() method of your
> MIDlet.

I already did it. Apologize me is my last e-mail
wasn't clear enough, but what I was trying to tell
that i believe JUnit uses the "main" method with parts
my J2ME codes, so the tests throws some Errors, like
when i try to capture a resource as stream. When i use
the code, outside JUnit, it works and nothing happens.

> Also, be aware that there is no reflection in
> JavaME, so you build your test
> suites differently in J2MEUnit than you do with
> JUnit.

How I build? I'm really having some problems with J2ME
and JUnit...

> --
> Cedric
>
>
> On 1/24/06, Brunno Silva <brunno.silva@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > Dear list-members,
> >
> > I had some problems when I started to use JUnit, a
> > week ago. After some research, I figure out that
> the
> > problem was the J2ME sandbox. I created my first
> test
> > case to test a simple class used by a MIDlet, and
> it
> > didn't work because it's not possible to do
> something
> > like that:
> >
> > public static void main (String args[])
> > {
> > The J2ME code...
> > }
> >
> > And i think that what the framework do, right?
> Well,
> > as I said before, it's impossible to do that
> because
> > of the J2ME sandbox. I looked for some kind of
> recipe
> > in the JUnit Recipes book, but I didn't find
> anything
> > about that or about other kinds of sandbox tests
> > (Indeed, i didn't looked in J2EE chapters, maybe
> > there's something about test a servlet, but I'm
> not so
> > sure if it also has a sandbox concept). So, do you
> > know a solution to my problem?
> >
> > Brunno Silva
